canvass.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to try to persuade people to support a political party, politician, plan etc by going to see them and talking to them, especially when you want them to vote for you in an election
canvass.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: Candidates from all three parties were out canvassing in Darlington today.
The US has been canvassing support from other Asian states.
Chapman spent the rest of May canvassing for votes.
canvass.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to ask people about something in order to get their opinion or to get information
canvass.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: Police canvassed the neighborhood, but didn’t find any witnesses.
canvass.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to talk about a problem, suggestion etc in detail
canvass.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: A committee was set up to canvass the city’s educational options.
canvass.translation[1].definitions[0].de: to ask people about something in order to get their opinion or to get information
canvass.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: People were canvassed for their opinions on the scheme.
canvass.translation[1].definitions[1].de: to try to persuade people to support someone or something
canvass.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: The US has been canvassing support from other Asian countries.
